document.docTitle: Sciurella cylindrica Galea & Maggioni & Di Camillo 2021, comb. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Towards a better understanding of the genus Sciurella Allman, 1883 (Cnidaria: Hydrozoa: Plumulariidae): evidence from an integrative study

Material examined.
MHNG-INVE-0137407, Indonesia , Bali , near Tulamben , -8.291824°, 115.609316°,
20 m
,
29 Jan. 2020
: a profuse colony composed of sterile stems up to 15 cm high, GenBank :
MZ 099711
(16S),
MZ 099675
(18S),
MZ 099658
(28S).— AMS Y.617, Australia , Darwin , off Rail Pier , -12.46667°, 130.83333°, depth unknown,
Jul. 1929
: two stem fragments, one sterile, the other bearing female gonothecae, both as parts of a profuse colony, identified by J.E. Watson (unpublished) as
Nemertesia cylindrica ( Kirchenpauer, 1876 )
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 9. Details of three different stems of
Sciurella cylindrica ( Kirchenpauer, 1876 )
from the same colony, showing variation in the arrangement of cladia: bipinnate (A), transition from bipinnate to pinnate (B), pinnate (C). All from sample MHNG- INVE-0137407. Scale bar: 1 mm.

FIGURE 10. Diagrammatic illustration of the arrangement of hydrocladia along mature stems of
Sciurella cylindrica ( Kirchenpauer, 1876 )
from Bali, in lateral (above) and apical (below) views.

FIGURE 11. Structure of the stem in
Sciurella cylindrica ( Kirchenpauer, 1876 )
. A . Internode showing the distribution pattern of the nematothecae. B, C . Cladial apophyses from two different stems, in lateral view. D . Detail of the axil of a cladial apophysis in frontal view, showing mamelon above and associated lateral nematothecae. From samples: MHNG-INVE-0137407 (A, B, D), AMS Y.617 (C). Scale bars: B–D = 200 µm; A = 500 µm.

FIGURE 12. Distribution of the stem nematothecae in
Sciurella cylindrica ( Kirchenpauer, 1876 )
. A, B . Two portions of a stem, each showing a few successive internodes and their nematothecae. C–F . Close-ups of four cladial apophyses seen laterally, showing variation in the number of their associated nematothecae. All from sample MHNG-INVE-0137407. Scale bars: C–F = 200 µm; A, B = 500 µm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Remarks. The description of the trophosome given above is based on the profuse, though sterile, material from Bali (MHNG-INVE-0317407). The two stems, including one fertile, from Australia (AMS Y.617) are similar in structure, and the morphology of the gonotheca described above is based on one of them.

As noted in the description, the stems are generally unbranched; in a few instances, a stem internode gives rise (perpendicularly to a given, generally distally-placed, internode) to a secondary stem that rapidly curves upwards at an acute angle with the original stem, the secondary stem adopting a vertical posture, as well. Branched stems were also reported by Watson (2000: 49) .

As noted in the introduction, the synonymy of this species was, for a long time, a matter of debate.
Plumularia cylindrica Kirchenpauer, 1876
was based on a syntype ( Table 1 ) and, although the general morphology of the cormidia in those specimens proves identical (compare Fig. 14F and 14G ), their cladia are reportedly said to have been inserted slightly differently in each of these materials 20 . Unfortunately, this statement could not be checked, as the syntype material was destroyed by fire in 1943 (Helma Roggenbuck, pers. comm. ) 21 . Given some differences in the arrangement of cladia noted by some authors (see below) and the high similarities of their cladial internodes, it can be reasonably assumed that both materials were conspecific.

Antennularia cylindrica Bale, 1884
, whose holotype was not reexamined, is reportedly very similar to
P. cylindrica
(see footnote 5), and their respective cormidia are proportionally the same (compare Fig. 14E and 14F, G ), suggesting that both nominal species are undoubtedly conspecific, with Kirchenpauer’s hydroid having priority, under the combination
Sciurella cylindrica ( Kirchenpauer, 1876 )
, comb. nov. (see below, under «Genetic results and discussion», our arguments in favor of maintaining the genus
Sciurella
as valid).

21 The specimen from Zamboanga bore the catalogue number 3691, and that from Zamboanga the number 3692; both were housed in the Zoological Museum, Hamburg , Germany prior to their destruction during World War II.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 13. SEM study of
Sciurella cylindrica ( Kirchenpauer, 1876 )
(part). A, B . Portions of stems with either bipinnate (A) and pinnate (B) arrangements of cladia. C, D . Details of internodes belonging to two different stems with bipinnate cladia. E, F . Details of stem apophyses supporting cladia from two different stems. From sample:s MHNG-INVE-0137407 (A, B, D, E) and AMS Y.617 (C, F). Scale bars: E, F = 100 µm; D = 200 µm; A–C = 500 µm.

FIGURE 14. Cormidia, nematothecae and gonothecae of
Sciurella cylindrica ( Kirchenpauer, 1876 )
. A–H . Various cormidia in frontal (A), lateral (B, D–H) and apical (C) aspects. I–K . Lateral (I) and mesial nematothecae, the latter seen both laterally (J) and adaxially (K). L, M . Immature (L) and ripe (M) female gonothecae. From samples MHNG-INVE-0137407 (A–C, I–K), AMS Y.617 (D, L). Figure E is redrawn after Bale (1884 , as
Antennularia cylindrica
), F and G after Kirchenpauer (1876 , as
Plumularia cylindrica
; F from Java, G presumably from Zamboanga), H after Schuchert (2003 , as
Nemertesia indivisa
), and M after Watson (2000 , as
Nemertesia cylindrica
). Scale bars: I–K = 50 µm; A–H = 200 µm; L, M = 300 µm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Since no notable differences are exhibited by the cormidia of
S. cylindrica
compared to those of
S. indivisa
, some authors [ e.g. Kirkpatrick (1890) , followed by Billard (1908 , 1910 , 1913 ), Bedot (1917) , Bale (1919) , Pennycuik (1959) , Schuchert (2003) ] regarded them as conspecific. However, although sometimes discrete, size differences appear nevertheless constant among the materials examined in the course of this study:
S. indivisa
has always longer internodes compared to
S. cylindrica
and, occasionally, their distal end is provided with an internal, annular ridge of perisarc (compare Fig. 4A–F and 14B, D–H , respectively).

Short cormidia, similar to those present in our material, are met with in the sterile specimens identified by Schuchert (2003) as
N. indivisa
( Fig. 14H ), suggesting that the correct specific assignation of his hydroid should be
S. cylindrica
. Its «laterally held hydrocladia […] directed towards sides, in opposite pairs» ( Schuchert 2003: 216 , fig. 63B) further supports this assumption.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 15. SEM study of
Sciurella cylindrica ( Kirchenpauer, 1876 )
(continued). A, B . Nematothecae associated to the stem apophyses supporting the cladia. C . Portions of cladia. D . Two cormidia from neighboring cladia seen laterally. E . Fronto-apical view of a cormidium. F . Latero-frontal view of a hydrotheca. From samples: MHNG-INVE-0137407 (A–D) and AMS Y.617 (E, F). Scale bars: B, F = 50 µm; A, D, E = 100 µm; C = 200 µm.

FIGURE 16. SEM study of
Sciurella cylindrica ( Kirchenpauer, 1876 )
(continued). A . Portion of fully-fertile stem. B–D . Female gonothecae (note aberrant twin gonotheca in B). E . Distal part of a gonotheca showing slit-like aperture. F . Nematothecae, note the adaxial emargination of the wall of their upper chamber. All from sample AMS Y.617. Scale bars: F = 25 µm; E = 50 µm; D = 200 µm; C = 300 µm; B = 500 µm; A = 2 mm.

TABLE 2 . Comparative measurements (in µm) of the species discussed herein. N. A. stands for not available, ø for diameter, and “hyd” for hydrotheca. The asterisk indicates that the same measurements were indicated by Billard in his 1910 and 1913 works on Challenger and
Siboga
hydroids, respectively; consequently, it is not possible to attribute these measurements to one of them with certainty.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Watson (2000) discovered, for the first time, fertile specimens of a
Nemertesia
-like hydroid with deep hydrothecae and urn-shaped gonothecae provided with nematothecae, thus demonstrating that her material «cannot be
N. indivisa » ( Watson 2000: 51 )
. The gonothecae in her specimens seem to have been even more ripe than those observed by us in sample AMS Y.617, as their apertures were wide open, and flanked by two blunt, lateral lobes of perisarc ( Fig. 14M ). In contrast, the most mature gonothecae we observed had slit-like, rounded apertures ( Fig. 16E ), while some others, decidedly immature, were closed ( Fig. 14L ).

As noted above, the insertion of cladia along the stem seems variable in this species. Kirchenpauer (1876: 45) described them as opposite, the four cladia of an internode actually adopting a bipinnate arrangement, a situation also met with in both Schuchert’s material (2003: fig. 63B) and ours from Bali . Bale (1884: 146) , however, observed in his unique specimen of
A. cylindrica
that each stem internode bore «from one to three whorls of ramuli, each whorl consisting of three, which alternate in position with those above and below», a condition met with in the fertile Australian fragment studied herein (sample AMS Y.617). Watson (2000: 49) observed verticils «of up to eight around each internode, reducing to four or five in distal stem region». In our opinion, these differences are probably related to the age of each stem, similarly to the situation met with in
S. indivisa
(see remarks under that species).

The number of nematothecae associated to the cladial apophyses of the stem seems equally variable: «about five in and around each axil» ( Bale 1884 ), «up to four […] and 1–2 or more close to apophysis» ( Schuchert 2003 ), «two or three flanking mamelon at base of apophysis» ( Watson 2000 ), commonly 2–3 (but occasionally up to 4) in sample AMS Y.617, and from as few as 2 to as much as 6 in our pinnate and bipinnate stems, respectively, from Bali .

Distribution. Indonesia : Java [ Kirchenpauer (1876) , as
Plumularia cylindrica
n. sp. ]; Kei Islands [ Schuchert (2003) , as
Nemertesia indivisa ( Allman, 1883 )
]; Bali (present study). Philippines : Zamboanga , ( Kirchenpauer 1876 , as
Plumularia cylindrica
n. sp. ). Australia : Port Curtis, QLD [ Bale (1884) , as
Antennularia cylindrica
n. sp. ; doubtful record, without description and figures, by Pennycuik [(1959), as
N. cylindrica ( Kirchenpauer, 1876 )
]; Murray and Warrior (= Tudu) islands, QLD [ Kirkpatrick (1890) , as
Sciurella indivisa Allman, 1883
] ( Fig. 19 ). Depth range: 6–39 m (compiled from the references given in the synonymy and our data).
